Award.AbstractNarration:
New technologies for the 21st century, with applications from LCD displays to touch screens and solar cells, involve the use of some metals that were not mainstream Earth resources just a few decades ago. Human innovation has led to new uses for indium, including the production of indium tin oxide (ITO), a substance that is both electrically conductive and optically transparent. These properties permit its use as the active component in the touch screens of smart phones, tablets, and related devices. As a result, the demand for indium increased three-fold from the 1990s to the mid-2000s, and ITO has been responsible for much of this increased demand. The research proposed herein will not only improve our understanding of the distribution of indium in the crust of the Earth, but will aid in the exploration for new indium-bearing ores, and thereby, help provide for the future indium needs of the country.

The primary sources for indium include massive sulfide deposits, vein deposits including granite-related veins, and other granite-related deposits. Indium is most commonly recovered from sphalerite, a zinc sulfide mineral. As part of this work, experiments will be performed to close critical gaps in our knowledge concerning the distribution of indium among the crystalline, aqueous, and molten phases of sub-volcanic magmatic systems, as well as the thermodynamics of the incorporation of indium into sphalerite under ore-forming conditions. Results of the research will permit quantitative estimates of the magmatic-hydrothermal efficiency with which indium can be removed from magmas, and be incorporated into sphalerite-bearing ores. The proposed research will permit explorationists and researchers to test hypotheses for the formation of high-temperature indium-bearing ores. This project is supported via the NSF FY14 Sustainable Chemistry, Engineering, and Materials (SusChEM) initiative.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mining has both direct and indirect impacts on the United States and global economies.  The extraction and utilization of Earth resources has permitted advances in the growth of building and material technologies.  Vast quantities of rock and mineral material, e.g., phosphate deposits, play an important role in maintaining our agricultural presence on the world stage. Other materials, including sand and gravel, are integral components of construction and are used to build and maintain the infrastructure in our urban and rural environments. Conversely, mining of smaller volumes of light and base metals, such as aluminum, copper and zinc, support this national infrastructure. On a smaller scale, the mining of technology elements, elements generally consumed at a low rate but with critical importance to electronic and other devices, provides the chemical components necessary to make advancement in the technology fields.

Indium, a chemical element with properties that are beneficial to many technology industries, is present in low concentrations in the crust of the Earth, generally less than one part in one million. In fact, it is the 65th most common element in the crust of the Earth.  Indium has a rare set of properties including a low melting point.  Additionally, when combined with small amounts of tin and oxygen, indium is both semi-transparent and conductive. For this reason, it has become an essential element in touch-screen devices, and the demand for those products continues to increase.   At present, the United States’ thirst for indium is satiated nearly entirely by foreign imports.

Given the low concentration of indium in the Earth, and the apparent difficulty with which Earth processes create high concentrations of the element, there is a need to better understand the behavior of indium in geologic systems. In fact, there is no single ore deposit where indium is the primary target element. In the rare instance where indium reaches high concentrations, for example, at the Mount Pleasant Deposit in New Brunswick, enrichment is often related to granite magmatism. Researchers have suggested that, at Mount Pleasant, indium was concentrated in high-temperature, magmatic-hydrothermal fluids exsolved from granitic magmas, and subsequently deposited as indium-rich minerals at low-temperatures. Therefore, it is crucial to understand how indium partitions in geologic materials and how it forms potential exploration targets with high indium concentrations.  Work of this type can provide security for uninterrupted indium supply to meet defense and technologic needs of the country into the future.

As part of the research completed here, laboratory experiments were performed to evaluate the distribution of indium in minerals associate with felsic igneous rocks -- granites.  Questions such as, what mineral phases concentrate indium, and what physical parameters lead to that concentration, can be answered as part of this work. Results from this work can be used by exploration geologists as one of the aids in their toolbox to gain better success in identifying indium-rich targets and critical mineral discovery to meet the needs of todays advanced technologies.
